Unsigned DIS Report Status : Unsigned DISCHARGE SUMMARY NAME : DRICKKIH , NEY UNIT NUMBER : 560-94-66 ADMISSION DATE : 09/27/97 DISCHARGE DATE : 10/04/97 PRINCIPAL DIAGNOSIS : Metastatic breast cancer . ASSOCIATED DIAGNOSES : Dehydration , generalized anxiety disorder . HISTORY AND REASONS FOR HOSPITALIZATION : This 75-year-old woman presented on week prior to admission with nausea . An enlarged liver was noted and ultrasound and CT scan showed multiple probable metastatic lesions . She presented on the day of admission with nausea and weakness and was admitted for observation and coordination of treatment . PHYSICAL EXAMINATION : She was a weak , elderly woman in a wheel chair who could not walk without assistance . Blood pressure 140/90 , pulse 80 , no cervical , supraclavicular or axillary adenopathy . On the breasts , multiple , erythematous , scaly plaques with underlying induration and inversion of the nipple on the right , left breast without masses . Abdomen : Liver span 12 cm firm with mild , right upper quadrant tenderness . LABORATORY DATA ON ADMISSION : Included a hematocrit of 41 , a white of 10,500 , platelets of 298 , alkaline phosphatase of 162 , potassium of 3.3 and remaining liver function tests and electrolytes normal . EKG showed normal sinus rhythm without abnormalities . Chest x-ray was clear . RESUME OF HOSPITAL COURSE : The patient was begun on intravenous hydration shortly after admission because of very poor PO fluid intake . Diagnostic work up included a fine needle aspiration of her right breast lesion which revealed ductal carcinoma , with estrogen and progesterone receptor status pending at the time of discharge . She had a bone scan which showed multiple areas of increased uptake , particularly in L1 , L3 and L4 , as well as the left sixth posterior rib . This corresponded to a site of pain reported by the patient . Her abdominal CT scan showed multiple lesions in the liver with enlarged periportal lymph nodes , cholelithiasis , and a left adrenal mass thought to likely represent metastatic disease . During her hospitalization , the main issues were pain control and nausea . Her pain was ultimately helped most by a regimen of oxycodone and oxycontin , and nausea responded to p.r.n. Trilafon . She was somewhat sedated on this regimen , and her standing Serax dose was reduced with substitution of Klonopin . She was seen by Radiation Medicine for palliative XRT to the painful lesions in her LS spine , and radiation therapy was begun on 10/2/97 with the plan for approximately 10 daily treatments . She required considerable encouragement to maintain PO intake , and required intravenous hydration to achieve adequate fluid intake during her hospitalization . A Physical Therapy evaluation could not be completed because of her degree of pain and nausea . She is being discharged to Linghs County Medical Center , with plans for continuing her tamoxifen pending estrogen receptor status availability which should be available within the coming week . She will also continue x-ray therapy treatment and being physical therapy as tolerated . CIMEG R.
